{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2963859,"name":"Allison Conrad","username":"scubadiv3r","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/scubadiv3r/{size}/234274_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-03T15:08:56.882Z","cooked":"

This is not a post asking for, nor wanting, advice on the merits of star/loop CAN bus, no gremlins please

I’ve been doing a bunch of research into finding a good ‘hub connector’ for a star topology robot, namely something connecting the CAN port on the Rio to all of the other CAN devices. Mostly been looking into pre-existing COTS solutions, but wondering if other teams have found something reliable.

canbus640×970 5.4 KB

Something along these lines, where it’s just a bunch of connector ports in 2 buses, one for high and one for low. I’m not against a custom PCB solution, but figured it would be worth asking around if anyone had ideas for how to handle this already.

Playing With Fusion - CANstar 4-Drop is one option

These look pretty close to what I’m looking for, I’m just hoping for something long enough for everything to plug into to eliminate the need for a bunch of these hooked together

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2021-08-03T15:31:32.937Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":22,"reads":389,"readers_count":388,"score":192.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395356,"topic_slug":"connectors-for-star-topology-can","display_username":"Allison Conrad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24617,"username":"gerthworm","name":"Chris Gerth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20690,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6421 Mentor // TWIST Program Director"},"post_url":"/t/connectors-for-star-topology-can/395356/3","custom_user_title":"6421 Mentor // TWIST Program Director","reactions":[{"id":"hugs","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2963866,"name":"Rick Lance","username":"rlance","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rlance/{size}/8537_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-03T15:45:41.699Z","cooked":"

Since a lot of the devices come with the 3 pin servo connectors we have looked at using these splitters. As one of our fall projects we are going to attempt to run the CAN along servo wire and have these inserted wherever we need to connect a motor in. I think it should work, but we shall see.

We’ve gone with a custom PCB solution in the past: GitHub - RoboLoCo-5338/CAN-PCBs: A Star topology for the CAN Bus using a PCB.

@Arvind_S made the original design for this back in the day.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2021-08-03T15:51:27.816Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":362,"readers_count":361,"score":142.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":395356,"topic_slug":"connectors-for-star-topology-can","display_username":"Alex S","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/RoboLoCo-5338/CAN-PCBs","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - RoboLoCo-5338/CAN-PCBs: A Star topology for the CAN Bus using a PCB.","clicks":83}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34339,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5338 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/connectors-for-star-topology-can/395356/5","custom_user_title":"5338 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2963868,"name":"Sean Lavery","username":"Lil_Lavery","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lil_lavery/{size}/65226_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-03T15:51:32.863Z","cooked":"

1712 has made good use of wire taps like these. While not single hub like you’re looking for, they give you the option to pursue a similar concept with a short CAN bus between your RoboRio and PDP, with taps branching off to your devices. Essentially, your high and low wires between your PDP and Rio become your “hub.” Moreover, it also gives you the flexibility for alternative ways to route your bus, if your design requires it.

scubadiv3r:

I’m just hoping for something long enough for everything to plug into to eliminate the need for a bunch of these hooked together

Keep the stubs under 1 ft, you’re good. Longer is possible too, with the right conditions.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2021-08-03T16:11:34.799Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":23,"reads":341,"readers_count":340,"score":218.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":395356,"topic_slug":"connectors-for-star-topology-can","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.ti.com/lit/an/slla270/slla270.pdf?ts=1627955537673","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":36}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/connectors-for-star-topology-can/395356/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2963872,"name":"Allison Conrad","username":"scubadiv3r","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/scubadiv3r/{size}/234274_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-03T16:24:41.416Z","cooked":"
gerthworm:

Keep the stubs under 1 ft, you’re good. Longer is possible too, with the right conditions.

Would you mind clarifying this quick (I read the documentation on it, just want to make sure I know what you mean). I’ve always put a terminating 120ohm resistor across one pair of wires on a motor controller, and then I’m looking to connect the other pair into a big can bus hub near the Rio (I’ve previously used a bunch of smaller groupings funneling down into the Rio, and it just not as clean of a solution as I would like).

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2021-08-03T16:24:41.416Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":329,"readers_count":328,"score":115.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":395356,"topic_slug":"connectors-for-star-topology-can","display_username":"Allison Conrad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20690,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6421 Mentor // TWIST Program Director"},"post_url":"/t/connectors-for-star-topology-can/395356/8","custom_user_title":"6421 Mentor // TWIST Program Director","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2963873,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-03T16:33:47.523Z","cooked":"

If you want something authoritative on CAN topology, see links referenced here: The best Can bus connectors - #56 by nuttle.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2021-08-03T16:33:47.523Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":317,"readers_count":316,"score":88.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":395356,"topic_slug":"connectors-for-star-topology-can","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/the-best-can-bus-connectors/390654/56","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"The best Can bus connectors","clicks":74}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":20690,"username":"scubadiv3r","name":"Allison Conrad","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/scubadiv3r/{size}/234274_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/connectors-for-star-topology-can/395356/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2963877,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-03T17:32:18.360Z","cooked":"

Sure - I’m specifically referring to section 4.8 in the TI document I linked, which in turn refers to “The Standard” (ISO 11898:1993) indicating a maximum unterminated stub length of 0.3m.

Additionally, that same section refers to critical length calculations (which include wire electrical propagation constants and rise/fall time of the driving chips). These in turn may be used to achieve longer stub lengths (like, an order of magnitude longer) without losing signal integrity.

scubadiv3r:

I’ve always put a terminating 120ohm resistor across one pair of wires on a motor controller

I’m not entirely sure this aligns with what I’d expect… I’m reading here that the there is one resistor per node on the bus. This doesn’t align with the doc that Nuttle posted:

image756×98 36.8 KB

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2021-08-03T17:32:18.360Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":317,"readers_count":316,"score":83.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":395356,"topic_slug":"connectors-for-star-topology-can","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/connectors-for-star-topology-can/395356/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2963885,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-03T18:18:48.321Z","cooked":"

Having used “Star” (technically it’s actually called “Bus” in this configuration) topology for >5 years now, we’ve gone thought a few different solutions. As you also discovered, there aren’t a whole lot of good solutions for this in COTS products, but here’s what we tried…

Initially, we attempted to use a pair of “small”-gauge grounding bus-bars (one for yellow, one for green). This worked, but was obviously not an ideal solution due to the size, weight, and screw-terminal connections.

After that, we discovered these Anderson PowerPole 8-port bus modules from PowerWerx which worked great and were easy to use, but the down-side is that CAN wire is quite small for the Anderson PP15/30/45 connectors which made crimping the connections difficult, and also still a bit heavier than they needed to be.

Our latest solution has been to have some custom PCBs made by JLCPCB which we designed using their free EasyEDA tool. These 20-port modules (we also made a 6-port version) weigh almost nothing, cost almost nothing, and accommodate connectors with standard “PWM” size (2.54mm) hole spacing. Rather than PWM connectors though, we opted to use these locking 2-pin MOLEX PCB connectors and their associated male-end hardware which have worked out well for us for the past few seasons.

In spite of what the nay-sayers might say, in the years we’ve used this configuration, the only issues we’ve ever encountered with the CAN network have been due to physical wiring issues as a result of user-error. But that said, since these errors almost never take the entire network down (unlike how they might on a daisy-chained system), it hasn’t caused any catastrophic failures during a match, and it’s also much easier to troubleshoot since only the affected device appears as “disconnected”. Though we do occasionally use runs longer than 1ft (we try to minimize them as much as possible), it’s never caused any noticeable impact on network connectivity or performance.

We’ve run on our custom CANJunction PCB the past two seasons and haven’t had problems.
Sources/BOM: GitHub - jcorcoran/CANJunction: PCB project to aid CAN wire distribution

Our topology is easier to imagine as a long single run w/ terminating resistor at the end, w/ all our devices tee-ing off along the central bus.

We use WAGO connectors between all the can connections that we know we might have to disconnect (e.g. between removeable mechanisms and the robot), and solder the connections together for everything that is permanent, Granted we use it for daisy chaining, But should be fine for star topology. I will say though, Star sounds like more weight than well thought out daisy chaining. (There’s also many other issues that can be had with star, But this isn’t a Star vs Daisy Chain thread.)

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":28,"updated_at":"2021-08-04T02:43:31.274Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":258,"readers_count":257,"score":61.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":395356,"topic_slug":"connectors-for-star-topology-can","display_username":"770352","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28522,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/connectors-for-star-topology-can/395356/19","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2963954,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2021-08-04T03:25:21.268Z","cooked":"

Not Star Topology, but 3468 has been doing more a “bus” config with one main “loop” between RIO and PDP and all the other devices on as short an extension as possible to reduce signal reflections and other potential interference that can come from the long wires in a star topology (though in all honestly, for the size and length of runs in most FRC bots it is perfectly fine). Our goal with this was to create a bus where we could add/remove devices without EVER needing to disconnect the Bus, reducing the worries of someone forgetting to plug it back together when removing or swapping a device.

For our Bus Topology we’ve used these splice-on connectors:

amazon.com

Along with these quick disconnects:

amazon.com

The upside of these is that you can have the main loop of wire be literally just one long twisted pair, and you can easily add another device along any part of that main bus by just attaching another splice to it.
The Downsides are that its a lot of points of failure, they can be picky about the thickness of the insulation on the wire, and it can be hard to tell if you have a bad splice, even though we never had that issue ourselves after 3 years using them.

This coming year, we are planning to try this instead:

amazon.com

The upsides being we have fewer points of failure per device, and can still remove a device without disconnecting the whole bus, by just leaving the connector in place and removing the wires from the third leg.
The downside is that you do have to add a cut to the bus at each connector, and additional logistics are required if you want to remove the connector after removing a device (I’d recommend using a couple wagos, or perhaps these?

amazon.com
